departments.name: Ministry of Justice

attributes.action: Keep all widespread species of amphibian and reptile in S5 & 8 of the WCA 1981
attributes.background:
Keep all of our widespread species of amphibian and reptile from Schedules 5 and 8 of the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.

Do not change the criteria that will result in the detriment to reptiles and amphibians. 

Improve the legal protection for reptiles and amphibians in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
Changing criteria to protect endangered species only is a move in the wrong direction. All reptile and amphibian species need more protection from human activity as populations are struggling.

We have seen a decline in all species for decades. If these changes go ahead, we could see species getting locally wiped out. Also a potential disease risk as people could sell and transport species.

We don’t want them all to become endangered in the first place. Prevention is the best cure

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Review and reform laws on the private keeping of Dangerous Wild Animals (DWA)
attributes.background: Latest research (Born Free 2021) revealed that DWA Act licences were issued for at least 3,951 animals in Great Britain in 2020; and the number kept as ‘pets’ has increased since 2000. Current legislation fails to adequately address animal welfare and takes no account of wildlife conservation.
attributes.additional_details:
We are calling for a comprehensive review, leading to far greater restrictions on the trade in and private keeping of wild animals in the UK based on:

•Whether individual welfare needs can be met, and owners have the necessary qualifications and experience
•Whether trade is likely to compromise the conservation of species in the wild
•Potential environmental concerns, such as the escape of invasive species
•Full consideration of the risks to public and animal health & safety, including zoonoses.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce 3 point penalty on driving licence for litter thrown from any vehicle
attributes.background: Increase penalties for throwing litter from any vehicle 3 points on their driving licence. To include not putting rubbish in the bins in lay-bys etc. Human waste / bottles of urine increase to 4 points.  It is hoped this will get the message across that littering is unacceptable as well as illegal.
attributes.additional_details:
The roads in our country are a disgrace as far as litter is concerned, it is antisocial, dangerous to the environment and wildlife.  Drive along any road or pull into a lay-by to see the extent of this. Get our country clean again, we are one of the worst in Europe now.  The amount of bottles filled with urine thrown from trucks and lay-bys full of litter including human faeces, shameful. 
There are man voluntary litter pickers doing a great job but it is too dangerous to pick the main roads.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Review travel advice and travel corridor list for African countries
attributes.background: The Government should review its travel corridor list and advice for travel to African countries, in line with the same metrics used for the rest of the world. If metrics of cases per 100k and testing levels were used, this could enable travel to Eastern and Southern Africa, to start with.
attributes.additional_details:
1. Humanitarian: The African continent relies heavily on international travel for £130bn income and 25m jobs. Each African travel job typically supports 8-10 dependents, helping to support up to 250m people across Africa.
2. Wildlife: More eyes on the ground in Africa should reduce poaching or rhino, elephant and pangolin and subsistence killing of animals for bush meat.
3. UK Jobs: Protect UK jobs across tour operators, travel agents, tourist boards, airlines, marketing and PR companies.

departments.name: Department for Transport
Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Remove the otter’s protected species status
attributes.background: The Eurasian otter (Lutra Lutra) is now firmly established in the river systems across the UK and appear to be in far greater numbers than anyone can recall.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the protection afforded by a number of priority species lists and The Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 should be removed as it is no longer appropriate, in order to protect and maintain a balanced riverine environment.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of all non-organic pesticides to the general public
attributes.background: Many non-organic pesticides can currently be sold to anyone in the UK without any checks or training. They should be banned from sale, online and in person, to the general public.
attributes.additional_details: 41% of insects around the world are threatened with extinction, including due to use of pesticides, alongside habitat destruction and climate change (Wildlife Trusts). We've seen a 68% decrease in population sizes of mammals, birds, amphibians, reptiles and fish between 1970 - 2016 (The Living Planet Report 2020). There is a wealth of experience that shows you can home garden successfully without non-organic pesticides, yet these kill billions of insects each year, which also contributes to the deaths of birds, mammals and other life that need them.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require local authorities replace roadside grass with wild flowers
attributes.background: We want roadside grass, including verges and roundabouts, to be replaced with wild flower 'meadows'. The Government should pass legislation to require local authorities to implement this policy.
attributes.additional_details:
This proposal should be beneficial to the environment and wildlife, require less mowing once established, look better, and require less use of harmful weedkillers.
 
It also should not impact on driver safety as should only grow 1 to 2 feet high and not impact upon a driver's view.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban plastic label and clothing fasteners and incentivise reuse of plastic items.
attributes.background:
Require manufacturers to find alternatives to plastic hooks, tags and loops on clothing (e.g. paired socks, folded packaged shirts, hanging loops on tops) and other products. 
Require shops to charge for clothing hangers or operate a return/refund scheme to incentivise customers and reduce waste.
attributes.additional_details: Phasing out single use plastic is a challenge, but we need to be moving more quickly where obvious alternatives exist or where the plastic items are simply unnecessary. Plastic label fasteners, hooks and tags are used throughout the clothing industry and on innumerable other products - these are snapped, cut, disposed of - at risk to wildlife in many cases, and never used again. Banning these items and requiring deposit-return schemes for clothing hangers would be a step in the right direction.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of plastic 6 pack rings in the UK
attributes.background: I want the Government to ban the use of plastic 6 pack rings in the UK due to the damage they cause to the environment.  They're particularly damaging to wildlife and have been banned already in some parts of the world.
attributes.additional_details: Although consumer pressure is already persuading some manufacturers to abandon plastic 6 pack rings it would be better if there was an outright, legal ban. Only the government can pass a law to do that.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Incorporate wildlife tunnels in the HS2 plans to mitigate ecological damage
attributes.background: Create regular tunnels under the railway to connect habitats and provide safe passage for wildlife. This should be a mixture of small tunnels for small mammals, invertebrates and amphibians, large tunnels for deer and badgers, and culverts for aquatic/semi-aquatic life.
attributes.additional_details: Overground areas of HS2 pose a variety of threats to wildlife by blocking movement or causing direct mortality. Wildlife tunnels can mitigate these effects by connecting fragmented urban and rural habitat and reducing collisions - it has been extremely successful with other infrastructure projects across the world. Connectivity is vital for maintaining genetic diversity and allowing animals assess different territories, resources and mates; all vital for preventing further species decline.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Review the approval of fish barriers at Hoveton Great Broad
attributes.background: The Government should review the Environment Agency decision to grant a license to install fish barriers and re-examine the results of the 7 year study demonstrating the importance of Hoveton Great Broad to fish and wildlife in the Broads.
attributes.additional_details: Angling is said to be worth over £100 million to the broads economy now at risk by these plans. I am concerned that the Heritage Lottery funding for the project appears to have been obtained on a false prospectus and due process not followed in the permitting decision with formal objections from Environment Agency fisheries experts seemingly disregarded and Water Framework Directive requirements potentially breached along with SAFFA's requirement on the EA to protect, enhance and improve freshwater fisheries, protect spawning fish and areas where fish spawn.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Regulate wildlife food so it’s safer for hedgehogs, and all mammals & birds
attributes.background: Shockingly there are currently no regulations on foods sold to be given to wildlife. These foods can contain ingredients that are unsuitable or even harmful.
attributes.additional_details:
We are calling on the Government to regulate these products, so only foods that are suitable for particular animals can be sold as such.
 
Sadly, well-meaning people are buying products labelled as food for particular animals, but they often contain ingredients that can cause the animals that eat it health problems, or even death. We are therefore calling on the government to regulate these products.
 
On 30th July 2020, hedgehogs were added to the Red List for British mammals and classified as vulnerable to extinction. Ensuring food sold as suitable for hedgehogs is safe could help protect this species.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make mountain hares a protected species in the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981
attributes.background: The conservation status of UK mountain hares, a native species, is currently unfavourable. We urge the Government to amend legislation to provide an equivalent level of protection for mountain hares in England & Wales to that conferred on more abundant Scottish mountain hares.
attributes.additional_details: Mountain hares, a UK Biodiversity Action Plan priority species, exist in England as a highly vulnerable, very small and isolated population in the Peak District. Current legal protection is wholly inadequate and fails to protect against factors which contribute to significant population decline, such as over-shooting, snaring, trapping, hunting & coursing. Continued unregulated human activity in conjunction with environmental factors could prove catastrophic to this population.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of flying plastic rings to help protect marine wildlife
attributes.background: Flying Ring, Frisbees with holes whatever you want to call them, are harming our marine wildlife. The sale of them needs to be banned. Every year there are reports of hundreds of seals ending up injured or dead because of a simple toy.
attributes.additional_details:
Flying rings get embedded into seals necks and cause, I should imagine, a lot of pain.

Seal pups are apparently inquisitive mammals so often play with these rings when they find them. It then gets stuck on their neck and as they grow it gets tighter and tighter until eventually they choke or starve to death. Please ban the sale.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the use of peat in gardening and horticulture
attributes.background: Peat is vital in fighting climate & ecological breakdown, as peat bogs store vast amounts of carbon and provide wildlife habitat. Using peat based compost destroys peat bogs. We need to ban the use of peat in gardening & horticulture.
attributes.additional_details:
• 3 million cubic metres of peat sold for horticultural use annually in UK, ⅓ from UK peatlands (IUCN http://bit.ly/peat-extraction-horticulture) 
• 20 million tonnes carbon dioxide lost to atmosphere annually from UK’s damaged peatlands (IUCN http://bit.ly/peat-climate) 
• Peatland destruction releasing vast amounts of CO2 (New Scientist http://bit.ly/peatland-destruction)  
• Peatlands support many important species & unique ecosystems (IUCN http://bit.ly/peat-species)

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a wildlife corridor in place of HS2
attributes.background: This wildlife belt - a 330 mile long stretch of woodlands, hedgerows, wetlands, orchards and meadows - would be the UK's longest nature reserve and have a massive impact on nature recovery across the UK, serving as a conservation area, a critical link between distant habitats and a living seed bank.
attributes.additional_details: We are in the midst of a pandemic, witnessing an extinction of plant and animal species on an unprecedented scale and heading towards a climate catastrophe. Saving lives, protecting and regenerating natural habitats, supporting local economies – all are a matter of urgency and must be given priority over hugely expensive, long term infrastructure projects that are bound to fail the test of time. Further costs, destruction and CO2 emissions needed to complete HS2 works cannot be justified.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Regulate wildlife food so it’s safer for our UK hedgehogs, mammals & birds
attributes.background: Wildlife food isn’t regulated. Anything can be in the food & sold to the public as suitable. But it could be harmful, of poor quality, even fatal or not nutritionally correct. We request a team be set up to agree on safe, nutritious food, specially designed for all our UK hedgehogs, mammals & birds.
attributes.additional_details: UK wildlife is depleting fast with destruction of habitats & climate crisis. It is more important now than ever to give a helping hand before it disappears completely. The State of Nature Report says that hedgehogs have declined more than 50%, 25% of UK mammals & 50% of birds are at risk of extinction. We need help to get wildlife food regulated. The general public are willing to help but need to be able to provide good quality food to actually improve outcomes for our UK wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Review the safety, environmental and wildlife impact of reservoirs
attributes.background: In February our lovely dogs, Coco and Spotty, perished in a local farm reservoir. It was not fenced and had a new polypropylene lining which means that, when wet, it is so slippery it is impossible for anyone (human or animal) to climb out.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government should:

- Commission research into the safest, most effective, most environmentally-friendly and most wildlife-friendly way to capture and store rainwater on farms.

- Require land owners to add secure perimeters to their reservoirs such as cargo netting or fencing.

- Ensure all water resource management grants include ring-fenced funding for robust health and safety measures

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase funding for flood defences for East Anglia
attributes.background:
We need the Government to provide funding to ensure that infrastructure designed to drain & protect East Anglia from flooding is restored and improved to its full capability.
 
The system must be capable of dealing with the pressures of the 21st century & the future challenges from global warming.
attributes.additional_details:
The threat of flood is real. As seen in December 2020: Homes were flooded, businesses were shut, national infrastructure was closed (A14), people evacuated from their homes and businesses and wildlife habitats destroyed.
 
If this issue is not addressed with urgency this is a man-made disaster waiting to happen. If the flood defences cannot express the surge of water quick enough the defences shall be breached and flooding of a great economic and humanitarian will happen. Action is needed now.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban use and sale of non-silent fireworks
attributes.background: Why can't we learn from 20/21 New Year when there were laser and light displays and silent firework displays only? This should ensure that celebrations do not cause nuisance that can cause upset and trauma to pets, military veterans and sensitive children.
attributes.additional_details:
It is really an awful time for our wildlife, livestock, pets, military veterans and sensitive children at this time of year.
Not only is it about everyone's safety and well-being, it's also about every animals well-being.
We are supposed to be a nation of animal lovers.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Protect Jones’ Hill Wood from being destroyed by HS2
attributes.background: Stop Jones’ Hill Wood from being destroyed due to HS2 development. Leave this beautiful, ancient woodland alone.
attributes.additional_details: Jones’ Hill Wood is a beautiful woodland area that inspired Roald Dahl to write ‘Fantastic Mr. Fox’. Not only is it a part of history but also a home for wildlife and a stunning place that people can visit. It allows for people to be educated on nature and offers them a stunning environment to enjoy.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK by 2025.
attributes.background: We would like the UK Government to ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK by 2025. Manual plastic toothbrushes are a notorious example of harmful plastic waste, and there are a variety of environmentally friendly alternatives in the market to move forward with.
attributes.additional_details: In the UK alone, 264 million manual plastic toothbrushes are thrown out every year. Each one of these plastic toothbrushes is non-biodegradable, meaning they'll last in the environment for over 600 years causing damage to wildlife and littering our country. There are already a variety of green alternatives available today, like bamboo toothbrushes which are readily biodegradable. Toothbrushes do not need to be harmful to the environment, so let's ban manual plastic ones.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban Jetskis from coastal waters and inland waterways
attributes.background: Jetskis are a hazard to wildlife and the natural environment, often being driven too fast for wildlife and people to respond and get out of their way. Users sometimes harass and chase wildlife, they are often unable to see some flora and fauna which lies just below the surface.
attributes.additional_details: Our wildlife is in crisis and we must respond quickly.  There have been promises of more protection and reversing declines. Jetskis are designed for speed and thrills and in many cases are used in fairly shallow waters. They are not compatible with the protection of our marine environment in coastal waters and inland waterways.  Important flora and fauna can be harmed and disturbed by these speeding motorised water craft. Swimmers and divers can also be at risk of harm. We need an outright ban

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Create a nationwide network of pollinator passages, to form The Bee Superhighway
attributes.background: We want the government to highlight, promote and support the importance of creating pollinator networks nationwide. A super highway for pollinators that connects landscapes ward by ward, borough by borough, county by county and region by region, thus building a network of habitats for pollinators.
attributes.additional_details:
A third of British wild bees and pollinators are in decline. If current trends continue, some species will be lost from Britain indefinitely.
Pollination is mutually beneficial to plants and pollinators. Pollinators are an essential component of the habitats and ecosystem that we and many animals rely on for food, shelter and well-being. This network, The Bee Superhighway, will foster that and help the long term sustainability of food production and wildlife livelihood and we must encourage it.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban balloon releases which are harmful to wildlife
attributes.background: Balloon releases can be harmful to wildlife and can cause plastic waste pollution. Seals and birds get tangled up in the plastic waste left behind. It is illegal to drop litter in the streets and it should be illegal to release balloons into the air.
attributes.additional_details:
Plant a tree or erect a bench, but please stop these balloon releases
Prevention of even more plastic pollutants

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase penalties for illegal off-road driving
attributes.background: Penalties for illegal off-road driving should be increased, with greater minimum sentences/fines and vehicle confiscation, to deter the huge increase in recreational off-road vehicle usage on grazing/common land which is damaging the livestock, our wildlife, environment and rural communities.
attributes.additional_details: Local wildlife, farmers, communities have relied on moorlands for generations and these vital peatlands are under threat with livestock unable to graze safely now. These illegal, vehicle users are shredding moorland to pieces. This problem has grown over the years and the increase is mainly adults using our moorland to exercise off-road bikes/4x4s and has now reached an overwhelming level. The huge increase in this illegal activity is damaging breeding grounds and the environment to a huge level.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make the sale and ownership of gin traps illegal within the UK
attributes.background: Since 1958 the use of gin traps has been illegal within the UK. However, in a loop hole it is still legal to own and sell these dangerous traps. Meaning anyone can possess and use these traps, making them a hazard to unsuspecting pets and wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Having a recent experience of my neighbour using these traps in an attempt to maim my own cats, it has been made clear to me , with some research, that these are still being used within the UK. Trapping and harming all manner of animals including cats, dogs, foxes, and hedgehogs etc.

These barbaric devices and are designed to inflict as much harm as possible to animals. This law needs to be changed as soon as possible to stop the pain being inflicted onto unsuspecting and innocent animals.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action:
Extend Dogs (Protection of Livestock) Act 1953 protections
to all Wildlife
attributes.background: Amendment: If a dog worries wildlife, the person in charge of the dog is guilty of an offence. The law to consider worrying of wildlife to include attacking, chasing in a way that may cause injury, distress, or being at large (not on a lead or otherwise under close control) near wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Every year swans & other wildlife are attacked by dogs. Despite warnings from the RSPCA & Police, habitual harrassment of wildlife by dogs is considered socially acceptable by many.

https://news.rspca.org.uk/2020/08/18/swan-was-most-injured-animal-rspca-officer-has-ever-seen-after-conwy-dog-attack/

This must end now!
